paper_metadata.title: Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers

evidence.observation_text: 10,827 mound features digitized from Soviet military topographic maps
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.

evidence.observation_text: 241 person-hours total effort
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)
evidence.extraction_notes: Total time investment broken down by contributor type

evidence.observation_text: 57 person-hours from staff
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)

evidence.observation_text: 184 person-hours from novice volunteers
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)

evidence.observation_text: Error rate under 6%
evidence.verbatim_quote: with an error rate under 6%
evidence.extraction_notes: Quality metric reported as upper bound

evidence.observation_text: Dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
evidence.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, welldocumented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

evidence.observation_text: Estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands
evidence.verbatim_quote: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages
evidence.extraction_notes: Archaeological context - estimate from cited sources

evidence.observation_text: Mounds range 10-50m diameter, 0.5-20m height
evidence.verbatim_quote: They were constructed of earth and rubble, and range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5â€“20 m in height

evidence.observation_text: TRAP catalogued 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley between 2008-2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey

evidence.observation_text: TRAP catalogued 431 mounds in Yambol region between 2008-2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey

evidence.observation_text: Soviet maps at 1:50,000 scale from 1980s, each covering ca 400 sq km
evidence.verbatim_quote: The goal of the work was to extract archaeological features from 1:50,000 scale Soviet military topographic maps dating to the 1980s. Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv. bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km.

source_location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.observation_text: Symbols occurred at average 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), ranging 50-400 per tile
evidence.verbatim_quote: Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

source_location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.observation_text: Mound symbols were moderately obtrusive with some aspects of shape or colour shared with other map symbols
evidence.verbatim_quote: The mound symbols were moderately obtrusive; some aspects of shape or colour were shared with other map symbols.

source_location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.observation_text: Records relatively simple: point for feature, record number, plus ten attributes
evidence.verbatim_quote: The records we sought to create were relatively simple: a point for the feature, a record number, plus ten attributes.

source_location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.observation_text: Maps of Yambol region contained 1,000+ targeted symbols
evidence.verbatim_quote: We knew that the maps of the Yambol region contained 1,000+ of these targeted symbols.

source_location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.observation_text: Students came from range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities, most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods

evidence.observation_text: 2010 desktop GIS digitization: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate challenging, many quit, those who continued required ongoing support
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support.

evidence.observation_text: 2010 volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time rendered desktop GIS approach unsuccessful
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

evidence.observation_text: 2017: faced short field season and little time for student training
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently.

evidence.observation_text: Approach stripped GIS functionality to essentials: layer selection, shape digitisation, annotation with validation and automation
evidence.verbatim_quote: As such, it stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation, with validation and automation to improve data quality.

evidence.observation_text: Simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitizing after only minutes of training
evidence.verbatim_quote: Geospatial data preparation and management was relegated to staff, while a simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training.

evidence.observation_text: FAIMS Mobile customization required 35 hours from undergraduate student programmer plus 4 hours from staff in 2017
evidence.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Server and device setup required 3 hours from staff in 2017
evidence.verbatim_quote: Setup of the server and configuration of the client devices in the field required 3 h from staff.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Map preparation required about 1.5 hours in 2017
evidence.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: File compression, upload, download took additional 2.5 hours in 2017
evidence.verbatim_quote: Monitoring file compression, upload to the server, and download to devices took an additional 2.5 h.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Training and supervision took no more than half hour of staff time across entire 2017 season
evidence.verbatim_quote: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: 2018: Adding validation took 1 hour from programmer
evidence.verbatim_quote: For the second season, adding additional validation to ensure population of latitude and longitude from GPS (see 'Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records' below) took 1 h of development from the programmer.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: 2018: In-field setup required 1 hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year)

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: 2018: Map preparation 30 minutes, file preparation and transfer 1.5 hours, training and supervision 30 minutes
evidence.verbatim_quote: map preparation 30 min, file preparation and transfer 1.5 h, and student training and supervision another 30 min.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Across both seasons: customization, setup, supervision took about 51 hours (36h programmer, 15h staff)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Initial customization and setup before fieldwork: 44 hours
evidence.verbatim_quote: Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Time during fieldwork to prepare/distribute maps and supervise: 7 hours
evidence.verbatim_quote: while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: Post-fieldwork quality checking of 4 maps required 6 hours staff time
evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, reexamination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

source_location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.observation_text: 2017: 125.8 person-hours over 5 rainy days, 8,343 features digitized from 42 maps (ca. 17,000 sq km)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km).

evidence.observation_text: 2017: Average time to record point feature was 54 seconds
evidence.verbatim_quote: The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices (representing work time excluding pauses between records).

evidence.observation_text: 2018: 63.6 person-hours, 2,484 features from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), average 92 seconds per record
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2018, use was more sporadic; participants who stayed at the base for any reason sometimes undertook digitisation. The system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), an average rate of one record every 92 s.

evidence.observation_text: Total: 189.4 student-hours, 63 seconds per record average
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, 10,827 point features, mostly burial and settlement mounds, were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record).

evidence.observation_text: 58 map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitized
evidence.verbatim_quote: Fifty-eight map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitised.

evidence.observation_text: Single point record could be associated with 11 attribute-value pairs, dataset contained up to 119,097 discrete values
evidence.verbatim_quote: Since a single point record could be associated with 11 attribute-value pairs, the dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (many captured automatically).

evidence.observation_text: 2010 desktop GIS effort: 915 features, 5-7 hours staff training/support/error-checking over 3 weeks
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5â€“7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals).

location.spatial_extent: over 20,000 sq km of Soviet military 1:50,000 topographic maps

resources.platform: FAIMS Mobile (Field Acquired Information Management Systems)

prior_work.output: 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley, 431 mounds in Yambol region
prior_work.method: pedestrian surface survey with manual digitization
